Fig. 1 Aldol condensation and consecutive reactions of acetone. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Yield of mesityl oxide, isophorone, IBMK and diisobutyl methyl ketone obtained in a catalytic reaction using 0.3 mol H18-DBT, 0.3 mol acetone and 0.03 mol of a) Al2O3, b) MgO, c) TiO2, or d) SiO2 (15 nm pore diameter) at 200 °C, normalized to the BET surface area of the respective metal oxide. Note that scaling of the y-axis in d) is reduced by two orders of magnitude. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Isopropanol and IBMK yields in the transfer hydrogenation reaction at 200 °C using 0.3 mol H18-DBT, 0.3 mol acetone and a catalyst amount corresponding to 0.3 mmol Pt; a) average and standard deviation of the yields (dashed lines: linear fit) over three different batches of the prepared benchmark catalyst (entry ‘BM’ in Table 2), b) commercial Pt/SiO2 catalyst (entry ‘Escat’ in Table 2), c) commercial Pt/C catalyst. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Influence of support pore diameter on the Pt/SiO2-catalyzed transfer hydrogenation of acetone to isopropanol and IBMK side product formation; conditions: 200 °C, 0.3 mol H18-DBT, 0.3 mol acetone, 1.2 mmol Pt (5 wt% Pt/SiO2). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Effect of the temperature of oxidative treatment of the 1 wt% Pt/SiO2 catalyst used in the transfer hydrogenation reaction; conditions of the transfer hydrogenation: 200 °C, 0.3 mol H18-DBT, 0.3 mol acetone, 0.3 mmol Pt; a) dispersion of Pt after reductive treatment; b) TOF of acetone transfer hydrogenation and IBMK formation. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Effect of the duration of reductive treatment at 200 °C of the 1 wt% Pt/SiO2 catalyst used in the transfer hydrogenation reaction; conditions of the transfer hydrogenation: 200 °C, 0.3 mol H18-DBT, 0.3 mol acetone, 0.3 mmol Pt; a) dispersion of Pt; b) TOF of acetone transfer hydrogenation and IBMK formation. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Effect of the reduction temperature in a 3 h reductive treatment of the 1 wt% Pt/SiO2 catalyst used in the transfer hydrogenation reaction; conditions of the transfer hydrogenation: 200 °C, 0.3 mol H18-DBT, 0.3 mol acetone, 0.3 mmol Pt; a) dispersion of Pt; b) TOF of acetone transfer hydrogenation and IBMK formation. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Effect of the Pt loading of the Pt/SiO2 catalyst used in the transfer hydrogenation reaction; conditions of the transfer hydrogenation: 200 °C, 0.3 mol H18-DBT, 0.3 mol acetone, 0.3 mmol Pt using 1 wt% Pt/SiO2, or 0.6 mmol Pt using 2 wt% Pt/SiO2, etc.; a) dispersion of Pt after reductive treatment; b) TOF of acetone transfer hydrogenation and IBMK formation. Cauerstr. 1 Erlangen 91058 Germany The storage of hydrogen in liquid organic hydrogen carriers (LOHCs) represents a safe and easy to handle storage solution for energy from renewable sources. Dibenzyltoluene (H0-DBT)/perhydro-dibenzyltoluene (H18-DBT) is a promising LOHC system due to its low flammability, wide liquid range and high storage density for hydrogen. However, this LOHC system requires high temperature heat (typically > 250 °C) for hydrogen release, which lowers the efficiency of the storage cycle if no appropriate source of waste heat is available. This disadvantage can be mitigated by transfer of the hydrogen onto an acceptor molecule such as acetone at mild temperatures, forming isopropanol which can be used as fuel in direct fuel cell concepts or represents a valuable chemical product. Herein, we present the development of an active and selective platinum on silica (Pt/SiO2) catalyst for the transfer hydrogenation of acetone using perhydro-dibenzyltoluene as the sole source of hydrogen. Relevant catalyst design parameters, such as the optimal pore size, Pt loading, reduction and oxidation temperatures/times, are identified and their influence on the catalyst morphology and performance is discussed. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords LOHC systems Dibenzyltoluene Transfer hydrogenation Acetone Aldol formation 1 Introduction The sustainable energy infrastructure of the future requires ways for large-scale energy storage to cope with the fluctuation of some of the renewable energy sources (e.g. sun, wind) and to facilitate transport from locations with high energy harvesting potentials to locations with high energy consumption. For this purpose, hydrogen offers great potential [1], but the low volumetric energy density and flammability of molecular hydrogen are major drawbacks for the technical implementation in many application scenarios [2–4]. The liquid organic hydrogen carrier (LOHC) concept circumvents these disadvantages as molecular hydrogen is chemically bound to fuel-like liquid organic molecules at the site of its production and released by a dehydrogenation reaction at the site of its consumption. The LOHC technology may simplify storage and transport between those sites, whilst relying on existing infrastructure for liquid fuels [1,3,4]. Dibenzyltoluene (H0-DBT) is a promising candidate for the chemical storage of hydrogen via the LOHC technology. Perhydro-dibenzyltoluene (H18-DBT) offers a good hydrogen storage density of 6.2 wt% in combination with a comparatively high density of 0.91 kg·L−1, a wide liquid range (−39 to 390 °C), and low flammability [1,3,5]. However, the release of hydrogen from H18-DBT requires reaction temperatures exceeding 250 °C due to the strongly endothermal nature of the dehydrogenation reaction to H0-DBT (Eq. 1) [1,3,5]. In contrast, process temperatures of 200 °C and below may be realized by transferring the hydrogen stored in H18-DBT to an acceptor molecule, such as acetone (Eq. 2), instead of releasing molecular hydrogen [6,7]. The hydrogenated acceptor molecule, isopropanol, represents not only a valuable chemical but can be applied in direct fuel cell systems to produce electric power (Eq. 3) [8]. (1) H 18 -DBT → H 0 -DBT + 9 H 2 (2) H 18 -DBT + 9 acetone → H 0 -DBT + 9 isopropanol (3) isopropanol + 0.5 O 2 → acetone + H 2 O In previous works, platinum on activated carbon (Pt/C) has been employed as a catalyst for the transfer hydrogenation of acetone by H18-DBT [8]. This catalyst system was demonstrated to enable high activity and selectivity towards the desired reaction. Furthermore, preliminary studies indicated that Pt-based catalysts outperform Pd, Ru, Rh, Au and Ni-based catalysts, which display low to zero-level activity for the transfer hydrogenation [7]. In this contribution, we present the use of metal oxide-supported catalysts for the same transfer hydrogenation. Metal oxide supports are common in technical catalysis and provide the advantage of a straightforward catalyst shaping. This facilitates the use of such catalysts in larger scale applications, e.g. by reduced pressure drop in catalytic fixed bed reactors and straight-forward liquid-solid-separation. Contrary, carbon-supported catalysts are usually applied as fine powders because robust shaping of these materials is a challenging task [9–13]. The choice of the metal oxide has to consider the fact that acetone may undergo aldol condensation reactions ( Fig. 1) in the presence of acidic [14–23] or basic sites [22–32]. The first condensation product is mesityl oxide, which may further condensate with acetone or can be hydrogenated to isobutyl methyl ketone (IBMK) in the presence of a reducing agent [14–16,18,19,21,23,27,30–32]. The consequence of aldol condensation is the consumption of the reactant acetone in an undesired side reaction. Moreover, the aldol condensation products are high-boilers that stick to the catalyst surface, a fact that will inevitably lead to coke formation and catalyst deactivation [16,26,30]. Metal oxide supports in heterogeneous catalysis exhibit different surface chemistries, including acidic (TiO2), basic (MgO), amphoteric (Al2O3) or mostly inert (SiO2) reactivities [33–36]. It can be assumed that the rather inert surface of SiO2 will be the least reactive for the undesired aldol condensation. Platinum on silica (Pt/SiO2) catalysts are well known in literature and have been used for different hydrogenation reactions [37–42] including the hydrogenation of acetone [37–39] as well as dehydrogenation reactions [43,44]. They are typically prepared by impregnation using varying reaction conditions [37,38,40–42,45–49]. Goguet et al. [46] and Miller et al. [48] provide an overview of the various impregnation and thermal treatment conditions in literature. The latter publication includes the effect on Pt dispersion over SiO2 support materials. Herein, a Pt/SiO2 transfer hydrogenation catalyst is developed for the application in transfer hydrogenation of acetone to isopropanol using H18-DBT as the sole source of hydrogen. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials For the catalyst synthesis, two silica gel materials with different porous structures were used (Acros Organics, 419282500, average pore size of 15 nm, particle size of 75–250 µm; Alfa Aesar, 42570, average pore size of 6 nm, particle size of 40–63 µm). Other tested support materials were aluminum oxide (PURALOX SBa 200, Sasol), magnesium oxide (LUVOMAG M074, Lehmann&Voss&Co.) and titanium dioxide (P25, Evonik). Pt(NH3)4(OH)2 (464813, Sigma Aldrich) was employed as Pt precursor. Commercial Pt/SiO2 (5 wt%, Escat 2351, ABCR) and Pt/C (5 wt%, 205931, Sigma Aldrich) catalysts were used as reference. All materials were used without pretreatment. For the transfer hydrogenation reaction, H18-DBT (Hydrogenious LOHC Technologies GmbH, Erlangen) with a degree of hydrogenation of 95% and acetone (>99.8% purity, 34850, Sigma Aldrich) were used. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis In a typical catalyst synthesis, 0.259 g of Pt(NH3)4(OH)2 were dissolved in 45 mL deionized water and mixed with 14.85 g of silica, which corresponds to a precursor salt content of 5.76 g L−1 and a targeted loading of 1 wt% platinum. The suspension was stirred for 1 h, after which it was dried in vacuo using a rotary evaporator at 60 °C and 40 mbar until no more bubble formation was observed. The impregnated catalyst was heated in a Nabertherm L9/11 muffle furnace with a P330 temperature control unit under a flow of synthetic air (70 mL min−1) at 150 °C for 3 h with a heating ramp of 5 °C min−1. It was then transferred into a ceramic boat which was placed inside a quartz tube (inner diameter: 42 mm, length: 550 mm) inside a horizontal tubular furnace (Carbolite type Gero) and heated up to 200 °C with a heating ramp of 5 °C min−1 under a flow of nitrogen (500 mL min−1). Upon reaching this temperature, the nitrogen flow was reduced to 450 mL min−1 and 50 mL min−1 of hydrogen were introduced to the feed stream for 3 h to activate the catalyst. Finally, the reduced catalyst was collected after cool-down under a flow of nitrogen. Deviations from the standard procedure are explicitly stated in the respective result sections. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The surface area A BET of the support materials was determined by nitrogen physisorption at liquid nitrogen temperature using a Quadrasorb SI analyzer (Quantachrome Instruments) and evaluated with the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method in the relative pressure range between 0.05 and 0.35 (Fig. S14-S23) [50]. Prior to analysis, the samples were degassed for 12 h at 200 °C and a pressure of 0.01 mbar. The pore size distribution was determined from the physisorption data with the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method in the relative pressure range between 0.5 and 0.75. Pore volumes V Pore and pore diameters d Pore were calculated as an average of the adsorption and desorption isotherm [51]. The platinum loading of a catalyst was determined using optical emission spectroscopy in a Ciros CCD (Spectro Analytical Instruments GmbH) with inductively coupled plasma (ICP-OES). A total of 100 mg of the catalyst was digested in 100 mL of a HCl-HNO3-HF mixture with a ratio of 3:1:1 in a microwave at 220 °C for 40 min. The concentration of platinum in the solution was determined using the spectral line of platinum at 214.123 nm. The dispersion of platinum on the catalyst surface D Pt was assessed using CO pulse chemisorption at 40 °C in an Autochem II 2920 (Micromeritics) after reduction for 200 °C in 20% H2/N2 for 1 h. A stoichiometric factor of 1 was assumed for the adsorption of CO on Pt. From the dispersion, the average Pt particle size d Pt was calculated assuming hemispherical particles. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was conducted using a Philips CM30. The particle size of Pt was evaluated by measuring at least 100 particles per sample using the software ImageJ (version 1.52a). 2.4 Catalytic tests The catalysts were tested in the transfer hydrogenation reaction using a 600 mL stainless steel (SS316) autoclave (Parr Instrument Company). The autoclave was equipped with a stirrer, argon line, internal cooling coil, rupture disk, and a liquid phase sampling line with a filter to prevent catalyst discharge and contamination of the samples. A perfluoroelastomer (FFKM) sealing ring was used due to the chemical resistance against H18-DBT and acetone. In a typical experiment, the autoclave was charged with 0.3 mol H18-DBT (corrected by the actual degree of hydrogenation), 0.3 mol acetone and the corresponding amount of catalyst for 0.3 mmol Pt. The 1:1 ratio of H18-DBT to acetone was selected as it has been shown previously to favor a high isopropanol yield [7]. The reactor was purged three times with argon (4 bar), the pressure was released, and the reactor was heated up to 200 °C under continuous stirring at 300 rpm, which took approximately 20 min. During heat-up the pressure increased from 1 bar to ca. 10 bar due to the evaporating reactant. After reaching the desired temperature, the stirrer speed was increased to 1200 rpm to ensure contact between the catalyst and the two reactant phases. Liquid samples were taken from the sampling line every 30 or 60 min depending on the reaction time. Approximately 1.5 mL of the effluent liquid from the sampling line were discarded to avoid contamination with the previous sample. Afterwards, approximately 0.2 mL were collected for off-line analysis. To elucidate the blank activity of the support materials, 30 mmol of the corresponding metal oxide (Al2O3, MgO, TiO2 or SiO2) were loaded instead of the catalyst. When testing catalysts with loadings other than 1 wt%, the same catalyst mass was loaded in each experiment to ensure a comparable physical composition of the slurry in the reactor. Consequently, the loaded amount of Pt scaled with the loading, i.e. 0.3 mmol Pt for 1 wt% loading, 0.15 mmol Pt for 0.5 wt% loading etc. 2.5 Gas chromatography analysis of liquid samples and calculation of yields and conversion The liquid samples were diluted with cyclohexane and analyzed in a Bruker type 430 gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a 50 m CP-Sil PONA CB column and a flame ionization detector. For each product i resulting from acetone, the integral A i of its peak in the chromatogram was used to calculate the mass in the GC vial m i,v using the mass of decane in the GC vial m Decan,v and the corresponding calibration factor f i (Eq. 4). From the mass of i in the vial, its mass in the reactor m i was calculated using the total sample mass m Sample,v and the initial mass of reactants m Aceton,0 and mH18-DBT,0 (Eq. 5): (4) m i , v = f i ∙ A i A Decane ∙ m Decane , v (5) m i = m i , v m Sample , v ∙ m Acetone , 0 + m H 18 − DBT , 0 The yield Y i was calculated using the stoichiometric coefficients ν i and the molar mass M i (Eq. 6). (6) Y i = ν j ∙ m i M i m Acetone M Acetone + ∑ j ν j ∙ m j M j The conversion X was calculated as the sum of all yields (Eq. 7) and the selectivity S towards a product i is defined as the yield of this product divided by the conversion (Eq. 8). For this, it was assumed that all reaction products have been found in the GC, so that the sum of all selectivities would equal 1 (cf. Fig. S1 and corresponding discussion). (7) X = ∑ i Y i (8) S i = Y i X The turnover frequency (TOF) towards a product i was calculated from a linear fit of the yield (Eq. 9) using the initial amount of platinum n Pt (calculated from the catalyst mass and loading as measured with the ICP-OES) as well as the dispersion D (measured with CO pulse chemisorption). The linearity of the yield as a function of time will be discussed in Section 3.2. (9) TO F i = n Acetone , 0 * dY i dt * n Pt * D 2.6 Molecular size determination The size of H18-DBT and acetone was determined by minimizing the molecule energy by MMFF94 in the software Avogadro (version 1.2.0) and determining the maximum distance in between two hydrogen atoms. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Choice of support material Several common metal oxide materials were initially screened to identify promising inert candidates to suppress support-induced side reactions. Bare Al2O3, MgO, TiO2 and SiO2 were tested for their activity towards aldol condensation and consecutive reactions of acetone. The morphological properties of the metal oxides were analyzed by means of physisorption ( Table 1). The BET surface area of all supports was in the range of 61–282 m2g−1. The yields of condensation products were normalized to the corresponding surface area to ensure comparability of the results. A significant amount of aldol condensation was observed over TiO2, MgO and Al2O3 ( Fig. 2). In contrast, only a minor amount of mesityl oxide was formed over SiO2 after prolonged exposure (note that the scale of the y-axis in Fig. 2d is two orders of magnitude lower than for the other metal oxides). This confirms the rather inert character of this metal oxide support in the present application and is in agreement with literature [35,36] as well as NH3-TPD measurements (Fig. S2). Hence, SiO2 was selected as the catalyst support of choice in the present study. 3.2 Catalyst evaluation A 1 wt% Pt/SiO2 catalyst prepared according to the standard preparation method (impregnation of SiO2 with a mean pore size of 15 nm with 1 wt% Pt, drying, oxidative treatment at 150 °C for 3 h, reduction at 200 °C for 3 h) shows a similar morphology to the support material ( Table 2; Table S1). The determined Pt dispersion of 63% is well in-line with literature values of the dispersion obtained with similar synthesis procedures [47]. In comparison, a commercial 5 wt% Pt/SiO2 catalyst exhibits broader pores and a higher surface area, while the platinum nanoparticles are poorly dispersed on the support surface resulting in dispersions below 3%. The Pt/C catalyst, which has been previously used for transfer hydrogenation [8], has rather narrow pores and a high surface area, well in line with literature values for this activated carbon-supported catalyst [52,53], as well as a moderate Pt dispersion. For the synthesized catalyst, an approximately linear increase of the isopropanol and IBMK yields over time was observed for low acetone conversion at a reaction temperature of 200 °C ( Fig. 3a; Fig. S3). This allows for comparison of the kinetics of the transfer hydrogenation reaction over this catalyst material depending on its synthesis parameters. Interestingly, no isopropanol formation, a low yield of IBMK of 2.4% and 0.3% mesityl oxide were observed with the commercial Pt/SiO2 catalyst (Fig. 3b), which is most likely due to the low Pt dispersion and some support reactivity. The Pt/C catalyst exhibited a similar isopropanol yield and a lower IBMK yield than the synthesized catalyst (Fig. 3c). However, the higher Pt loading and differences in the support morphology (Table 2) complicate the direct comparison with the synthesized catalyst. 3.3 Effect of pore size To investigate the influence of the pore size on the catalytic reaction, two catalysts were synthesized with the standard procedure and a platinum loading of 5 wt% (impregnation of SiO2 with 5 wt% Pt, drying, oxidative treatment at 150 °C for 3 h, reduction at 200 °C for 3 h) to ensure a sufficiently high yield of isopropanol for a reasonable comparative evaluation. Two different silica supports with a pore size of 6 and 15 nm, respectively, were used for the two catalysts. The maximum diameter of H18-DBT was estimated to be approximately 1.3 nm. Therefore, a cylindrical pore with a diameter of 6 nm can geometrically accommodate approx. 20 molecules of H18-DBT in its cross-section. In such an arrangement, most of the molecules can be expected to interact with the pore walls, i.e. cannot diffuse freely [54]. On the other hand, pores with a diameter of 15 nm can geometrically accommodate approx. 130 molecules of H18-DBT in the cross-section significantly reducing walls effects on diffusion. Acetone should not be affected by diffusion limitations due to its small maximum diameter of approx. 0.41 nm. In the transfer hydrogenation experiments, the TOF of acetone towards isopropanol is significantly lower over the catalyst with 6 nm pores compared to the catalyst with 15 nm pores ( Fig. 4). Considering the comparable dispersion of Pt in both catalysts (73% vs. 83% for 6 and 15 nm pore size, respectively) and the identical amount of Pt used in the experiments, the fact that the isopropanol formation with the large pore support catalyst is significantly higher is remarkable. This hints for a mass transport influence in the 6 nm pores. Similar effects have been discussed in literature for the H18-DBT dehydrogenation, where mass transfer influences were observed for pore diameters smaller than 30 nm [55,56]. It is noteworthy, that the activity difference with respect to IBMK formation between the catalysts supported on silica with different pore width is comparatively small. The first step of this reaction – the aldol condensation – requires acetone as the only feedstock molecule and acetone diffusion is fast. In a second step, the condensation product mesityl oxide is reduced to IBMK. No mesityl oxide has been observed over either of the two catalysts, showing that the second step is comparatively fast. This is consistent with literature as the C-C-double bond in mesityl oxide has been reported to be reduced faster in the presence of hydrogen than the C-O-double bond in acetone [19,23]. However, the TOF towards IBMK is lower than the TOF towards isopropanol as the amount of formed mesityl oxide in the reaction mixture is expected to be significantly lower than the amount of the reactant acetone. The slight increase of IBMK formation over the catalyst with larger pores indicates that the intermediate mesityl oxide or the product IBMK (maximum diameter of both molecules ~ 0.63 nm) might be mass transport limited in 6 nm pores, though less than H18-DBT. 3.4 Effect of the temperature and duration of oxidative treatment It has been discussed in literature that after impregnation and evaporation of water, a treatment of the Pt(NH3)4(OH)2/SiO2 catalyst in an oxidative atmosphere, such as air, can ensure the complete removal of the ligands [46,47,49]. Goguet et al. studied impregnation of SiO2 with Pt(NH3)4(OH)2 by means of temperature programmed oxidation (TPO). It was found, that NH3 desorbed between 100 and 200 °C and was oxidized by air around 270 °C, which resulted in the formation of N2 and N2O [47]. The latter process was exothermic and induced a pronounced increase of particle size in catalysts treated at temperatures ≥ 300 °C in air. After preparation of a Pt/SiO2 by the standard procedure (impregnation SiO2 with mean pore size of 15 nm with 1 wt% Pt, drying, oxidative treatment for 3 h, reductive treatment at 200 °C for 3 h) with different temperatures during the oxidative treatment in synthetic air, the maximum Pt dispersion was observed for the catalysts treated between 150 and 200 °C ( Fig. 5a). Low dispersions were observed after oxidative treatment at 100 °C, potentially due to residual ammonia being attached to Pt after incomplete oxidation of the precursor. This may prevent adsorption of CO during the pulse chemisorption experiment, while the Pt particles as such are still small (median of the particle size distribution: 1.2 nm) as verified by means of TEM (see Fig. S6). For this reason, no TOF was calculated for the catalyst treated at 100 °C since the active surface area of the platinum catalyst could not be precisely assessed. After thermal treatment of the catalyst materials at temperatures ≥ 300 °C, the concentration of particles with a diameter larger than 3.2 nm increased, which broadened the size distribution (see Fig. S6-S7). A nearly linear decrease in dispersion after oxidative treatment between 200 and 500 °C reflects the trends observed using TEM. These observations are consistent with the formation of mobile PtOx species under oxidizing atmospheres at temperatures ≥ 300 °C as described in literature [47–49]. The TOF of transfer hydrogenation to isopropanol (Fig. 5b) is similar for the catalyst materials that have been treated at temperatures ≤ 300 °C. For 150–300 °C, the Pt particle sizes mostly range between 0.8 and 3.2 nm (see Fig. S6-S7). While the increase of oxidation temperature to 300 °C leads to a significant decrease of particles smaller than 1.6 nm in favor of few particles larger 3.2 nm (slightly lowering the Pt dispersion), the reaction rate is hardly affected. This suggests that particles below a critical size, which may be approx. 1.6 nm for transfer hydrogenation, contribute less effectively to the overall reaction. This is in good agreement with the structure sensitivity of the H18-DBT dehydrogenation reaction that has been reported in literature [57]. According to these previous studies, H18-DBT dehydrogenation is most effective for supported Pt nanoparticles with an average Pt particle diameter of approx. 2.1 nm. Above 300 °C, the TOF of transfer hydrogenation decreases as expected from the enhanced loss in Pt surface area due to sintering during oxidative treatment, which has been observed in the TEM analyses (see Fig. S6-S7) and dispersion ( Fig. 5a). The TOF towards IBMK, on the other hand, increases with decreasing Pt dispersion. One possible explanation is the presence of acidic sites on the SiO2 surface, which are mostly responsible for the aldol condensation over SiO2. These sites bind the Pt precursor salt [46,48,58] and are then blocked by Pt nanoparticles formed during the catalyst synthesis. Therefore, if the dispersion of Pt is low, many acidic sites remain available inducing the significant formation of mesityl oxide. Subsequent transfer hydrogenation to IBMK competes with the transfer hydrogenation of acetone in the reaction system. Contrary to the temperature, the duration of the oxidative treatment at 150 °C hardly affected the Pt dispersion or catalyst performance. Even a short oxidative treatment at this mild temperature was found to sufficiently remove Pt ligands while even prolonged exposure times did not induce particle growth via sintering (see Fig. S5). 3.5 Effect of reduction temperature and duration The oxidative treatment induces formation of acidic PtOx species [47–49,59,60]. Prior to the use of the Pt/SiO2 catalysts in transfer hydrogenation, the catalyst materials prepared by the standard procedure (impregnation of SiO2 with mean pore size of 15 nm with 1 wt% Pt, drying, oxidative treatment at 150 °C for 3 h) were reduced using hydrogen at various treatment durations and temperatures. At 200 °C, the dispersion of Pt increased with reduction duration up to 2 h ( Fig. 6a), which is seemingly the time required for a thorough reduction at this temperature. The decrease of dispersion after reduction times exceeding 3 h hints towards a slow agglomeration of the reduced Pt particles over time. The influence of the reduction time on the TOF of acetone towards isopropanol is relatively small (Fig. 6b), whereas the TOF towards IBMK is strongly affected. Hence, it can be assumed that aldol condensation is not only catalyzed by support sites, but also by acidic PtOx species. Thus, while most Pt on the surface appears to be reduced after 2 h as indicated by dispersion measurements, the TOF towards IBMK rather suggests that a reduction time of at least 3 h is required for the full removal of the more acidic PtOx surface species. Variation of the reduction temperature suggests incomplete reduction after 3 h at 150 °C, while the dispersion of Pt is rather independent from the conditions at reduction temperatures ≥ 200 °C ( Fig. 7a). TEM measurements confirm that the average Pt particle size remains mostly constant over the studied range of reduction temperatures (see Fig. S8). This is in contrast to the observation under oxidative atmospheres (Fig. 5), but in agreement with a reported different mobility of the species present under reducing atmospheres [47,49]. The TOF of the acetone transfer hydrogenation to isopropanol increases with the reduction temperature in the reductive catalyst treatment prior to the transfer hydrogenation step (Fig. 7b). The TOF of IBMK formation decreases with reduction temperature to a minimum at 300 °C linked to a more quantitative reduction of the acidic PtOx sites. Higher reduction temperatures of the catalyst led again to an increase of IBMK formation. Our results indicate that a reduction temperature of 300 °C promotes some extent of Ostwald ripening (see Fig. S8) leading to a disproportionation of medium sized particles into smaller and larger particles. The larger particles may effectively catalyze the transfer hydrogenation (cf. Section 3.4), while the smaller particles suppress the aldol condensation by blocking acidic sites of the support. At 200 °C, the reduction is slow, but the PtOx species present on the surface after oxidative treatment are not particularly mobile at this low temperature [47] and therefore do not significantly agglomerate. On the other hand, the reduction is sufficiently accelerated at temperatures ≥ 400 °C to prevent Pt diffusion, possibly because metallic Pt is formed immediately and subsequently “pinned” to the surface. 3.6 Effect of platinum loading The amount of platinum on the catalyst is decisive for the mass-specific activity of the catalyst. Variation of the Pt loading between 0.5 and 4.1 wt% during the standard synthesis procedure (impregnation of SiO2 with mean pore size of 15 nm, drying, oxidative treatment at 150 °C for 3 h, reduction at 200 °C for 3 h) resulted in similar Pt dispersions on the catalyst ( Fig. 8a). Expectedly, the conversion scales with the loading of the catalyst as the overall catalyst mass (support + Pt) was constant throughout this series of catalytic testing (see Fig. S4). A maximum of the TOF for the transfer hydrogenation was observed for a loading of 1 wt% (Fig. 8b). We explain this finding with the inhomogeneous distribution of the platinum particles over the cross section of the support particle leading to an enrichment of Pt in an egg-shell manner. At low loadings, most Pt is found close to the external surface of the SiO2 due to the quick irreversible adsorption of Pt(NH3)4(OH)2 onto SiO2 as discussed in the literature [46]. At high loadings, on the other hand, the outer parts of the particle become saturated and a larger fraction of Pt precursor diffuses deeper into the porous network of the particle during impregnation. This reduces the effective use of these Pt centers in the mass transfer limited transfer hydrogenation (see above) using H18-DBT as the sole source of hydrogen. Interestingly, the TOF towards IBMK decreases steadily with the Pt loading (Fig. 8b). Our explanation is that at higher Pt loadings, similar to the scenario at high dispersions (cf. Section 3.4), more acidic support sites are blocked by Pt nanoparticles formed during catalyst synthesis. Note that less formation of mesityl oxide also reduces the competing transfer hydrogenation of mesityl oxide to IBMK and thus leads to a lower absolute IBMK yield at higher Pt loadings ( Table 3), which is especially remarkable considering the aforementioned higher acetone conversion. 4 Conclusion A Pt/SiO2 catalyst for the transfer hydrogenation of acetone by perhydro-dibenzyltoluene was developed, prepared, and evaluated. Several important parameters for producing an effective transfer hydrogenation catalyst could be identified and their further optimization may allow the synthesis of even better transfer hydrogenation catalysts for this application in the future: a) In contrast to other oxidic supports, using SiO2 as catalyst support can minimize the amount of side products from acetone aldol condensation. Pt(NH3)4(OH)2 is a suitable platinum precursor for the catalyst synthesis by wet impregnation. b) The average pore diameter of the support should exceed 6 nm to minimize detrimental influences by mass transport effects. Mass transfer restrictions affect primarily the concentration of the hydrogen source H18-DBT at the catalytic sites and thus the liberation of hydrogen for the transfer hydrogenation process. c) During catalyst synthesis, an oxidative treatment of the impregnated catalyst at 150 °C is required to ensure accessibility of the active phase, potentially by a complete removal of residual ligands. Higher temperatures under oxidative conditions eventually lead to sintering of Pt and, consequently, to a loss of active metal surface. d) During catalyst synthesis, a reduction step is required after the oxidative treatment of the catalyst material to ensure that all Pt surface atoms are in the metallic state prior to the transfer hydrogenation experiment. This enhances the formation of the desired product isopropanol while simultaneously lowering the formed amount of the main side product IBMK. A reduction at 300 °C for at least 3 h provides the lowest IBMK yield. e) A higher Pt loading on SiO2 decreases the IBMK yield and increases the productivity of the catalyst per volume and per total mass of catalyst. However, the Pt-based activity and the TOF decreases with higher loadings. A Pt loading of 1 wt% appears as reasonable compromise between these counteracting trends. f) To mitigate side product formation and maximize isopropanol yield, it is highly important to avoid formation of the mesityl oxide aldol condensation product in the first place. Once formed, the latter is readily hydrogenated to the main side product IBMK. In addition to the competing nature of this transfer hydrogenation, it also consumes hydrogen initially bound to the hydrogen carrier H18-DBT. Conclusively, three crucial parameters for the preparation of Pt-based catalyst for the herein studied transfer hydrogenation were identified: support material, pore size, and loading of Pt. Compared to other metal oxides facilitating a high dispersion of Pt, SiO2 may represent a superior support material due to suppression of major side reactions even though this support demands a considerable degree of attention to ensure an efficient dispersion of Pt. However, Pt(NH3)4(OH)2 is a suitable precursor resulting in robust catalyst syntheses yielding high dispersions. In particular the parameters of the reduction have little impact on the performance of the catalyst, as long as minimum duration of 3 h and minimum temperature of 200 °C are ensured. The pore size of the support is crucial for mass diffusion limitation of H18-DBT and (partially) dehydrogenated species, which demands for large pore sizes. Finally, high Pt loadings are highly recommended, but a trade-off must be made between improved space-time yields with lower formation of by-products and efficient use of costly Pt. Using the herein summarized catalyst design principles, we demonstrated that a highly selective transfer hydrogenation of acetone and H18-DBT is indeed possible with Pt/SiO2 catalysts. As isopropanol is a suitable fuel for direct LOHC fuel cells [61], the here presented investigations may contribute to the further exploration of a possibly highly attractive route for using cycloalkane-bound hydrogen in future emission-free electric power generation systems. coredata.dc:description: The storage of hydrogen in liquid organic hydrogen carriers (LOHCs) represents a safe and easy to handle storage solution for energy from renewable sources. Dibenzyltoluene (H0-DBT)/perhydro-dibenzyltoluene (H18-DBT) is a promising LOHC system due to its low flammability, wide liquid range and high storage density for hydrogen. However, this LOHC system requires high temperature heat (typically > 250 °C) for hydrogen release, which lowers the efficiency of the storage cycle if no appropriate source of waste heat is available. This disadvantage can be mitigated by transfer of the hydrogen onto an acceptor molecule such as acetone at mild temperatures, forming isopropanol which can be used as fuel in direct fuel cell concepts or represents a valuable chemical product. Herein, we present the development of an active and selective platinum on silica (Pt/SiO2) catalyst for the transfer hydrogenation of acetone using perhydro-dibenzyltoluene as the sole source of hydrogen. Relevant catalyst design parameters, such as the optimal pore size, Pt loading, reduction and oxidation temperatures/times, are identified and their influence on the catalyst morphology and performance is discussed.
coredata.dc:title: Development of an efficient Pt/SiO2 catalyst for the transfer hydrogenation from perhydro-dibenzyltoluene to acetone
